message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute cell-mediated rejection is characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells is seen in acute tubular necrosis, drug precipitation in the renal tubules is seen in drug-induced nephropathy, and granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane is seen in immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute, cell-mediated rejection is characterized by infiltration of lymphocytes into the tubules and interstitium of the transplanted kidney, making option B the correct answer. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells is a sign of acute tubular necrosis, drug precipitation in the renal tubules is a sign of drug-induced renal injury, and granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane is seen in immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated serum blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels and the fever and arthralgia suggest acute rejection of the kidney transplant. Among the options, lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium is typical for cell-mediated rejection. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells is more in line with acute tubular necrosis, drug precipitation in the renal tubules is not typical for rejection, and granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane is characteristic of immune complex deposition in glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of acute rejection after kidney transplantation. Acute rejection is mediated by T cells and would most likely manifest as a lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium upon biopsy. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells can be seen in acute tubular necrosis, drug precipitation can cause drug-induced interstitial nephritis, and granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane can be seen in immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated serum BUN and creatinine suggest renal dysfunction, and the fever and arthralgia suggest an immune reaction. Cell-mediated rejection is characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium. The other options are not consistent with the presentation of acute rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated serum BUN and creatinine, fever, and arthralgia are all possible signs of acute rejection. Among the options, lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium is characteristic of acute, cell-mediated rejection. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells suggests acute tubular necrosis, drug precipitation in the renal tubules suggests drug-induced kidney injury, and granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane suggests immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has elevated serum BUN and creatinine, indicating kidney dysfunction. The symptoms of fever and arthralgia suggest acute rejection. The most common characteristic of acute rejection on biopsy is a lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells can be seen with acute tubular necrosis, drug precipitation in the renal tubules may be seen with tubulointerstitial nephritis, and granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane is associated with immune complex deposition in membranous glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated serum blood urea nitrogen and creatinine, fever, and arthralgia following kidney transplantation suggest acute rejection. Among the options, lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium is the hallmark of cell-mediated rejection. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells is seen in acute tubular necrosis, drug precipitation in the renal tubules can lead to acute interstitial nephritis, and granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane suggests immune complex deposition in glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute, cell-mediated rejection is characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells would be seen in acute tubular necrosis. Drug precipitation in the renal tubules would be seen with drug-induced nephrotoxicity. Granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane is seen in immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has elevated serum BUN and creatinine, which suggest renal dysfunction. The fever and arthralgia suggest an inflammatory process, and if the patient is experiencing acute, cell-mediated rejection, the most likely biopsy finding would be a lymphocytic infiltrate of the tubules and interstitium. Sloughing of proximal tubular epithelial cells and drug precipitation in the renal tubules are not typically seen in rejection. Granular immunofluorescence around the glomerular basement membrane is seen in immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.
